results.notes:
Same fruiting as obs 404133.

I thought this may be Irpex lacteus. But the spores seem wrong for this species (shape/quotient wrong).

The appearance is very much like that of Dentocorticium portoricense, although the ellipsoid spores do not match those of D. portoricense. The spores look very much like those seen in the photo seen in the following link for Dendocorticium polygonioides (which I suspect is a misspelling of the genus) https://www.researchgate.net/... Index Fungorum does not recognize “Dendocorticium.”

results.notes:
On the base of a Monterey Cypress tree at a residence on the bluff overlooking Morro Bay.

Thallus thin, discontinuous, whitish grey with light yellowish orange areas where apothecia are originating. Apothecia <1mm, starting out with crusty white margins when erupting through the thallus and orange pruina on the disks, becoming plane with reduced thalline margins. Pycnidia not seen. Spore average size: 11.2×5.2×4.6µm (n=7). Ratio septum to length=0.41.

ID is best guess based on size of septum and white thallus, which fits with Arup 2009 and McCune 2012.

results.notes:
On bark of a Norfolk Island Pine in a residential yard overlooking Morro Bay, so hyper maritime fog influence. Still some work to do on this one, but here’s what I have now.
Thallus thin, white, K+Yish, with black prothallus between contiguous thallii. Epihymenium black, Exciple black, appears carbonized but need to do better check. Hymenium hyaline to slightly pinkish-orange tinged. Paraphyses conglutinated, need to examine branching and anastomosing still. Asci tholus hemi-amyloid in K/I, no ring observed, grumulosa type? Algae Trentopohlioid. Spores mostly 5(6)-septate, hyaline, fusiform, widest at middle, tapered to ends, somewhat curved, with a gelatinous sheath (see photo), average size 21.1×3.1µm (n=9), not spirally arranged in asci or breaking like Bactrospora.
In Ryan’s key Lecanographa is separated from Lecanactis by the grumulosa-type ascus and spores with gelatinous sheath. There aren’t many Lecanographa, especially with round ascomata. L. subdryophila seems to match fairly well, even down to conifer bark substrate.

results.notes:
On unknown hardwood ornamental tree bark overlooking Morro Bay, so hyper maritime fog influence. Not convinced this is Lecanactis salicina as there is no pruina on the apothecia. Doesn’t fit Cresponea either, although it is close.

Thallus thin, white, K+Y-O, C+Y faint (need to confirm!), Trentopohlioid. Apothecia about 0.5+mm, plane to slightly convex, epruinose throughout even when young, with a persistently raised rim lacking algae. Epihymenium black, K+greenish, hymenium hyaline, K/I+B, hypothecium brown, extending down from exciple. Exciple notably K/I-. Should still check for crystals in polarized light. Asci with a central K/I+B tube, ring not observed but deserves a better review, abietina type? Spores 8/ascus, not coiled or breaking, fusiform, hyaline, 3(4) septate and rarely to 6 septate, end cells longer, one end often attenuated, spores not halonate, average size 20.3×2.6 (n=4).

results.notes:
Leratiomyces ceres (Agaricales, Strophariaceae) Bogotá, Colombia
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/40641362
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/50875899

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

Basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, el Píleo mide entre 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse hacia el borde, con escamas fasciculadas originadas por restos del velo universal que forma un círculo a modo de collar cerca del borde. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, pruinoso. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

Primer registro de esta especie para Colombia. Segun Vasco-Palacios AM, Franco-Molano AE. 2013, la familia Strophariaceae esta representada por las siguientes especies:

Hypholoma sublateritium (Schaeff.) Quél.
Hypholoma subviride (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Dennis.
Melanotus alpiniae (Berk.) Pilát.
Melanotus cassiaecolor (Berk.) Singer.
Melanotus dumontii Singer
Naematoloma subviride (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) A.H.
Naematoloma udum (Pers.) P. Karst..
Pholiota aberrans A.H.
Pholiota apiahyna Speg.

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

2014-2020, Registros

2016, Publicación
https://www.researchgate.net/...
2020, Recopilación
https://mushroomobserver.org/414059?q=1JArw

A continuación, se realiza su respectiva descripción: basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, píleo de 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse con el tiempo, con escamas blancas y fasciculadas en el margen, originadas por restos del velo universal. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, de superficie pruinosa. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. En algunos ejemplares se logra observar un anillo en banda (rudimentario) adherido al estípite, delgado y efimero. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

El trabajo de microscopia se realizó con un Microscopio Zeiss de Luz Halogena 6v 30w y reactivos rojo congo, melzer e hidróxido de potasio (KOH) 5%. Se observan basidios tetraspóricos, claviformes de 31 × 8 µm, basidiosporas elipsoidales no amiloides, de color marrón a rojo oscuro, superficie lisa, ligeramente apiculadas, con poro germinativo evidente (0,8 a 1 µm). Cistidios fusiformes, de 35,7 × 12,7 µm en general se observan hifas paralelas y presencia de fíbulas.

Tomando como referencia los registros de los autores y los consolidados en la plataforma iNaturalista y gbif.org, la especie ha sido observada en Cota Cundinamarca, Engativá Bogotá D.C., Humedales del noroccidente de Bogotá (Humedal La Conejera, Humedal Cordoba, Humedal Tibabuyes, Humedal Torca-guaymaral), Humedal Santa Maria del Lago, Jardín Botánico José Celestino Mutis Bogotá D.C., Parque El Virrey Bogotá D.C., Parque La Florida Cundinamarca,Villamaría Caldas.

notes_fields.Macro:
Bright orange to red shelf fungus. Several basidiocarps of various sizes and shapes emerging from dead fallen Post Oak limb (Quercus stellata). The largest example was semicircular with a diameter of 6cm and 1.4cm thick at the base (at connection to bark). Smooth on top with angular pores on the bottom (approximately 5 pores per mm).
I referred to a paper “Mycosphere Essay 11: Fungi of Pycnoporus: morphological and molecular identification, worldwide distribution and biotechnological potential by Téllez-Téllez M” Mycosphere 7(10) 1500-1525 (2016) for identifying characteristics but this specimen did not match macro characters outline in the paper for P. cinnabarinus or for P. sanguineus, but seemed to share some characteristics from each.
One difference noted was in the KOH test for the specimen. One drop of 4% KOH on cap immediately turned very dark brown, not completely black as expected, drying to a brownish-tan color. P. cinnabarinus should color black and stay black. P. sanguineus should turn black and dry to greenish-brown. The KOH test seems to place this specimen nearer P. sanguineus but the angular pores would (according to Téllez-Téllez) put it near P. cinnabarinus.
I am fairly new at fungal identification, so I well could be missing important considerations.

My interest in it now is that appears to be none from ID’d as this species in GenBank. UNITE has two from BC but these two sequences seem to be very isolated from other Xeromphalina?
MF 03934 in case I can find some extra money for sequencing.

results.notes: Growing scattered in soil in a greenhouse. Annulus absent. Stems smooth, white, and not bruising. Cap margins not striate. Pileipellis composed of hyaline, rounded elements. Caulocystidia exclusively lageniform. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline and lecythiform. Cheilocystidia measurements: (15.5) 18.2 – 20.3 (22.9) × (5.9) 6.5 – 8.3 (8.8) µm, Q = (2.2) 2.24 – 2.9 (3.1); N = 10, Me = 19.1 × 7.5 µm; Qe = 2.6. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown, smooth, and possessing germ pores. Spore measurements: (7.8) 9.1 – 10.16 (10.2) × (6) 6.1 – 7.3 (7.7) µm, Q = 1.3 – 1.5 (1.7); N = 30, Me = 9.6 × 6.8 µm; Qe = 1.4

results.notes:
This lichen struck me because it’s clearly competing with the moss. Beyond that, I don’t know much. It has the characteristic of a rapidly spreading membrane which seems uncommon to me in the East. I have seen examples of that type of lichen in the west, but don’t recall the name. The lichen is very pale gray or green gray and is cracked into small polygons. There are small bumps and structures that look almost like tiny moss plants that have been covered by the lichen top membrane.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146030472 on January 7, 2023.

results.notes: Growing abundantly in mulch. Caps hygrophanous. Veils absent or scant. Gills not marginate. Pileipellis composed of rounded elements. Clamps present in the stipe trama and the lamellar trama. Caulocystidia mixed lageniform and clavate. Pleurocystidia scattered and lageniform like the chilocystidia. Cheilocystidia hyaline and lageniform. Cheilocystidia measurements: (25) 27.7 – 36.6 (50.1) × (6.3) 7.1 – 9.6 (10.9) µm, Q = (2.9) 3.2 – 5 (6.8); N = 30, Me = 32.6 × 8.2 µm; Qe = 4. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores dark brown in 1M KOH, thick-walled, and with germ pores. Spore measurements: (10.9) 11.5 – 12.8 (13.2) × (6.2) 6.7 – 7.6 (8.3) µm, Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 1.8 (1.9); N = 30, Me = 12.2 × 7.2 µm; Qe = 1.7.
